poem:
**Unseasonal Orchard**

In Wisley's green expanse, a mild December grins,  
figs and almonds bask where frost once nipped.  
Mediterranean whispers weave through Surrey's breeze,  
climate's changing script—unexpected plot—  
as English boughs bear fruit from foreign lands,  
nature adapting, flourishing, without winter's sharp touch,  
yet pondering, beneath each leaf, what tomorrow lays bare.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Fig and almond trees thriving in UK thanks to fewer frosts, RHS says Fig and almond trees are thriving in Britain as a result of fewer frosts, the Royal Horticultural Society has said. The lack of frost, one of the effects of climate breakdown, means plants used to warmer climes have been doing well in RHS gardens. Almond trees from the Mediterranean were planted at Wisley in Surrey several years ago, and without frost this". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
